fields.headline: Alberta declares state of emergency as wildfire forces Fort McMurray evacuation
fields.standfirst:
More than 80,000 residents ordered to leave city and at least 1,600 buildings destroyed as ‘nasty, ugly’ inferno rages in hub of Canadian oil sands industry

  • Worst of blazes ‘still to come’ after Fort McMurray evacuated
  • Have you been affected?
fields.trailText: More than 80,000 residents ordered to leave city and at least 1,600 buildings destroyed as ‘nasty, ugly’ inferno rages in hub of Canadian oil sands industry
fields.byline: Ashifa Kassam in Calgary and agencies
fields.body:
The Canadian province of Alberta has declared a state of emergency after a raging wildfire destroyed dozens of homes, engulfed several neighbourhoods and forced the hurried evacuation of the entire city of Fort McMurray.

More than 80,000 residents were ordered to leave the northern Alberta city after shifting winds saw the blaze go from being largely controlled to a “nasty, ugly” inferno as described by the local fire chief. By Wednesday more than 250 firefighters were fighting the fire, assisted by helicopters and air tankers. Officials estimated that 1,600 structures had been damaged or destroyed by Wednesday night.

As flames fanned south on Thursday, officials also issued mandatory evacuation orders for the Anzac, Gregoire Lake Estates and Fort McMurray First Nation communities located about 50km south of Fort McMurray.

After the evacuation order was issued, residents scrambling to make their way out of Fort McMurray sat in bumper-to-bumper traffic on the main road, struggling to see the road through the thick grey haze that blanketed the highway. Flames licked the road and ash rained down on vehicles, while air tankers and helicopters flew overhead. Gas pumps soon ran dry, leaving many residents stranded on the highway overnight.

“[With] the heat from the oncoming smoke and the flames, you could see mini-tornadoes forming near the road,” resident Jordan Stuffco told the Canadian Press. “It was something out of an apocalyptic movie.”

Authorities warned that the fire, which started on Sunday, was being fanned by hot, dry and windy weather. “The worst of the fire is not over,” said Bernie Schmitte of Alberta Agriculture and Forestry. “We’re still faced with very high temperatures, low relative humidity and some strong winds.”

Hours later the raging inferno forced authorities to declare a state of emergency. The province’s municipal affairs minister, Danielle Larivee, said the declaration would allow the province to better access external resources.

An accident on a nearby highway between an SUV and a tractor-trailer unit had resulted in fatalities and sparked an additional fire, added Larivee. It was not immediately clear if the accident was related to the evacuation. The driver and passenger of the SUV died on the scene.

Related: Wildfires in Canada force evacuation of Fort McMurray – in pictures

Officials said the fire had grown from about 1,200 hectares to span more than 10,000 hectares within two days. “We had a devastating day yesterday and we are preparing for a bad day today,” local fire chief Darby Allen said.

He described the wildfire as a “nasty, dirty fire” that was raging out of control, that defied efforts to suppress it. “There are areas of the city that have not been burned, but this fire will look for them and it will find them, and it will try and take them.”

On Tuesday 105 patients and clients – including nine newborn babies – were evacuated from city’s only hospital as flames approached.

With Fort McMurray the hub of the province’s main oil sands region, a number of oil sands work camps nearby were turned into impromptu housing for evacuees. Neighbouring communities also reached out to residents as they fled the flames, staffing recreation centres to provide shelter and bringing gas to stranded motorists.

Others made their way to the evacuation camps that had been set up outside the city or found lodging in the city of Edmonton, some 435km away, where they took stock of what they had left behind.

“When you leave … it’s an overwhelming feeling to think that you’ll never see your house again,” Carol Christian told the Canadian Press. Along with her son and cat, she had driven to an evacuation centre. “It was absolutely horrifying when we were sitting there in traffic. You look up and then you watch all the trees candle-topping … up the hills where you live and you’re thinking, ‘Oh my God. We got out just in time.’”

Rachel Notley, the Alberta premier, said about 10,000 evacuees had moved north to stay in the oil sands work camps. The bulk of the evacuees fled south to Edmonton and elsewhere, and officials said they eventually would like to move everyone south.

Shell said it had shut down production at its Shell Albian Sands mining operations about 60 miles north of the city so it could focus on getting families out of the region.

Suncor, the largest oil sands operator, said it was reducing production at its regional facility about 15 miles north of the city. Many other companies evacuated non-essential staff.

Chelsie Klassen, a spokeswoman for the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers, said all large oil sands facilities had emergency crews and plans for forest fires, noting all personnel would be evacuated and facilities would be properly shut to minimise the damage.

She noted 80% of oil sands deposits were deep underground and could only be extracted through drilling. The remaining 20% could be mined from the surface and was predominantly located north of Fort McMurray. It could burn under certain circumstances, but at a much slower pace considering its composition with sand.

Municipal authorities on Wednesday began detailing the damage that had been caused by the wildfire, including one neighbourhood where 80% of the homes were destroyed. Images on social media showed the flattened neighbourhood of Beacon Hill, the rubble of its many destroyed homes strewn about. In another neighbourhood, a dozen trailers also went up in flames, while serious losses were reported in several other areas.

Some in the city had as little as 30 minutes to evacuate, with many making it out with little more than their vehicle and the clothes on their back. “I didn’t have time for nothing,” said Shawn Brett. He had been at home when his friends called to warn him of the encroaching blaze. He jumped on his Harley motorcycle and made his way out, fighting his way through the smoke and flames that had engulfed his neighbourhood.

“I literally drove through the flames. I had ashes hitting my face and the heat from the fire was that bad,” he told the the Canadian Press. “Everything was jammed. It was nothing but the biggest chaos I’d ever seen.”

Justin Trudeau, Canada’s prime minister, said on Wednesday he had spoken to the Premier Notley, to offer the government’s support. “I really do want to highlight that Canada is a country where we look out for our neighbours, and we are there for each other in difficult times,” Trudeau told his Liberal caucus. “And certainly in Fort McMurray, the difficult times they are going through right now is something that we are going to unite around.”

He shot down earlier comments made by Elizabeth May, the leader of Canada’s Green Party, that linked the fire to the global climate crisis.

“One thing we know is that with climate change there will be more extreme events,” said Trudeau. “But, we know very well that placing a direct link between any fire or a flood and climate change goes a step beyond what is helpful and does not benefit a conversation we must have.”

The premier of Alberta said on Wednesday that she planned to head to Fort McMurray to get a firsthand look at the scope of the crisis. “Our hearts are with the families who have had to leave their homes in Fort McMurray,” said Notley from Edmonton.

Nearby communities have sent emergency personnel and vehicles to the city. The provincial government has also been in continuous contact with other provinces and the federal government, she said, and now has the resources needed to battle the blaze. “But of course the weather is the key issue.”

Queen Elizabeth said she was “shocked and saddened” by the news of the wildfires “Our thoughts and prayers are with all those who have been affected, and we send our heartfelt thanks to the firefighters and the other emergency workers,” she said in a statement.

The wildfire comes as a devastating blow to a city already reeling from the impact of slumping oil prices, said David Yurdiga, the MP for the area. The Alberta oil sands rank as one of the world’s largest reserves of oil. “Even with the destruction caused by the fire thus far we will need federal funds to get back on our feet,” he wrote in a statement. “This city has seen thousands of people leave their homes because of the downturn in oil. Fort McMurray cannot handle that and this wildfire.”

With Associated Press

fields.headline: More than 'just a poster boy'? Canadians on Justin Trudeau, six months in
fields.standfirst: Where some see openness, authenticity and vision, others detect only talk, a well-oiled PR machine and a new face on business as usual
fields.trailText: Where some see openness, authenticity and vision, others detect only talk, a well-oiled PR machine and a new face on business as usual
fields.body:
Canada’s prime minister is no ordinary politician – Justin Trudeau has been pictured balancing babies with one hand, dancing to bhangra music, and showing off his yoga skills. He’s also made headlines with his bold views on everything from drugs, to climate change and feminism. But, as the world looks on in wonder, how do people feel in Canada? Six months after he was sworn into office, we asked Canadians to tell us how they think Trudeau is faring.

The mood six months on

On 4 November 2015, Trudeau took office, after nine years of Stephen Harper’s leadership. Harper was known, among other things, for his contempt for the public’s right to know about his government’s activities, insisting that he choose who got to ask the questions at press conferences.

One of the biggest changes since he was voted out, according to those who responded, is that government is now much more open. Bobbie Jean Huff, 70, from Ontario summed it up saying: “Trudeau’s not a tyrant like Harper. There’s a new openness in the air. It’s refreshing.”

Barbara Densmore, 59, from Vancouver Island, says: “Justin has brought a level of intention, authenticity, openness, thoughtfulness and forward thinking that I’ve never before seen.” She adds: “I think the mood has changed for the more progressive thinkers in the country. It’s like having a light switched on after almost a decade of darkness. But there are a lot of people who are still having time adjusting to the light.”

Trudeau’s global outlook has also been a game-changer. Vicky, 29, from Toronto says: “He is bringing international attention to our country ... He won’t do everything he set out to do, but he is making a great effort to come out of the gate swinging on all his campaign promises.”

Sean, 24, from Toronto agreed: “The tone of government has changed a lot. People are more optimistic as the government responds more to concerns of everyday Canadians and takes on a more positive role internationally.”

There was general recognition that he is reinvigorating interest in the political process. Colin Mitchell, 18, from Vancouver says:“His emphasis on young people has truly reengaged a large segment of Canadian society. After nearly a decade of neglect, our current government has a demonstrated interest in the future of Canada.”

The policies

Although he’s only been in office for six month, many Canadians have been watching to see which policies he will stick to, and which ones he may abandon.

We heard from a lot of people who praised how he has handled the global refugee crisis. Christian, 20 from Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, says: “The acceptance of over 25,000 refugees was very popular and showed the Liberals intended to keep their promises. The gender parity in his cabinet was also extremely popular, as were his views on feminism as expressed at the World Economic Forum in Davos.”

Sue G, 55, from Ottawa agreed: “By welcoming Syrian refugees, Trudeau has reaffirmed the role of Canada as a humanitarian nation – and has refuted the myth that Muslims are terrorists.”

There was also a lot of support for his work to integrate indigenous communities in the country. One way he is doing this is by launching a national public inquiry into missing and murdered indigenous women. Trudeau also said his government would make significant investments in education and lift the 2% cap on funding for First Nations programs.

Dave T, 60, from Southern Ontario says: “The one policy change that is probably most significant would be the restoration of relations between Canada’s government and the indigenous people. Imagine my horror to learn that successive governments for over 150 years were engaged in systemic cultural genocide. To now have a government that has made it central to their mandate to respect and include these severely marginalised people in the decision making process will have a significant impact on Canada’s social fabric for many generations to come.”

However, Trudeau’s policies sometimes appear to be in conflict and many criticised his lack of action on bill C-51, the anti-terrorism law passed by the former Conservative government in the spring following homegrown attacks in Quebec and Ottawa.

Anonymous, 46, from Vancouver says: “The mood was pretty giddy just after the election, and his cabinet selections solidified that. But we’re still waiting for actual significant policy – C-51 is still the law, we still have first past the post for voting, and the time to change that before the next election is getting short. Trade deals and pipelines still lumber along. It’s still business as usual in most respects, which is not what I expected. I know it takes time to change things, but I would have liked to have seen at least one significant piece of legislation by now.”

Not blocking sales of arms to Saudi Arabia also proved unpopular. Guillaume Gervais, 32, from Toronto says: “He disagrees that ‘honour killings,’ female genital mutilation, forced marriage or other gender-based violence” are barbaric. They are just a different cultural practices for him. His thumbs-up for the sale of $15bn of weaponry to the Islamic State of Saudi Arabia is also outrageous and humiliating for Canadians.”

Gervais adds that on the positive side, the last budget his team proposed seems promising. “Canada’s infrastructure are deficient and are not keeping up with economic and demographic growth. His team doctor-assisted death legislation is also promising. It mostly leaves behind opinions from backward ideologies on the subject and focuses on the patient.”

A case of good public relations

Many of those who responded had their concerns that Trudeau was all talk – and great PR – but no action. “His team looks well prepared to manage him. He’s a poster boy with very little life experience. He never really had a job before jumping into politics a few years ago. Overall, Justin is a pretty good actor backed by a very well oiled PR machine,” says Gervais.

Anonymous, 46, from Toronto says: “He looks good but Canadians were looking for more than a change of clothes: they were looking for a whole different wardrobe. Instead it’s like the same elite wealthy people are running things the way they always did. And it’s really disappointing.”

However, others said that rhetoric in itself – even without action – can be powerful: “The best thing he has done for our country is his rhetoric. He has promoted respect for aboriginal peoples, acceptance of refugees and other cultures, the importance of multilateralism and humanitarianism ... Even without concrete policy, his rhetoric has resulted in a paradigm shift in the Canadian public on many key issues.”

Jury is still out

While it’s still really too soon to tell whether Trudeau will live up to the expectations, many people are now waiting to see what will happen in coming months. Peter Jakubiak, 36, from Ottawa, summed up the mood perfectly: “His policy ideas will face greater scrutiny as they are further rolled out and tested over time. So far his government seems open to input, committed to putting in the work, and not too proud to change or adapt course in response to criticism. This seems a fairly promising beginning to what will surely become a less forgiving general reception.”
